data.value: The box extends from the first quartile (Q1) to the third quartile (Q3) of the data, with a line at the median.  The whiskers extend from the box by 1.5x the inter-quartile range (IQR).  Flier points are those past the end of the whiskers. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box_plot for reference.
Show the caps on the ends of whiskers.
Show the outliers beyond the caps.
If given, all parameters also accept a string
The input data.  If a 2D array, a boxplot is drawn for each column in
.  If a sequence of 1D arrays, a boxplot is drawn for each array in

children.type_: Array or a sequence of vectors.

data.value: Whether to draw a notched boxplot (
).  The notches represent the confidence interval (CI) around the median.  The documentation for
describes how the locations of the notches are computed by default, but their locations may also be overridden by setting the

In cases where the values of the CI are less than the lower quartile or greater than the upper quartile, the notches will extend beyond the box, giving it a distinctive "flipped" appearance. This is expected behavior and consistent with other statistical visualization packages.
The default symbol for flier points.  An empty string ('') hides the fliers.  If
, then the fliers default to 'b+'.  More control is provided by the
If a float, the lower whisker is at the lowest datum above
, and the upper whisker at the highest datum below
, where Q1 and Q3 are the first and third quartiles.  The default value of
corresponds to Tukey's original definition of boxplots.
If a pair of floats, they indicate the percentiles at which to draw the whiskers (e.g., (5, 95)).  In particular, setting this to (0, 100) results in whiskers covering the whole range of the data.
is automatically set to (0, 100) (cover the whole range of the data) if
Beyond the whiskers, data are considered outliers and are plotted as individual points.
Specifies whether to bootstrap the confidence intervals around the median for notched boxplots. If

is None, no bootstrapping is performed, and notches are calculated using a Gaussian-based asymptotic approximation (see McGill, R., Tukey, J.W., and Larsen, W.A., 1978, and Kendall and Stuart, 1967). Otherwise, bootstrap specifies the number of times to bootstrap the median to determine its 95% confidence intervals. Values between 1000 and 10000 are recommended.
forces the value of the median for the corresponding dataset.  For entries that are
, the medians are computed by Matplotlib as normal.
.  Each entry that is not None forces the location of the corresponding notch (which is only drawn if
, the notches are computed by the method specified by the other parameters (e.g.,

where N is the number of boxes to be drawn.
The widths of the boxes.  The default is 0.5, or
produces boxes with the Line2D artist. Otherwise, boxes are drawn with Patch artists.
Labels for each dataset (one per dataset).

A dictionary mapping each component of the boxplot to a list of the
instances created. That dictionary has the following keys (assuming vertical boxplots):
: the main body of the boxplot showing the   quartiles and the median's confidence intervals if   enabled.
: horizontal lines at the median of each box.
: the vertical lines extending to the most   extreme, non-outlier data points.
: the horizontal lines at the ends of the   whiskers.
: points representing data that extend beyond   the whiskers (fliers).
: points or lines representing the means.
Draw a box and whisker plot.
Draw an estimate of the probability density function.
